title: Sync man pages with the actual options
Update documention of the --threads option in the man pages
Update rand dependency to 0.7
Add finalfrontier(1) man page
body:
Fixes #88

This is just a landing (man) page in case someone tries `man finalfrontier`. I am not sure if `finalfrontier completions` warrants its own man page. It's more something that a packager would use to generate the completion files (such as in the Nix derivation).

title: Run cargo {fmt,clippy} on just one target
body:
It is useless running these on each target, so only run on
x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu.

title: Remove Rust nightly from the build matrix
Merge ff-train-{deps,skipgram} into a single finalfrontier command
body:
The old utilities are now available as:

finalfrontier skipgram
finalfrontier deps

The `finalfrontier completions` command can be used to generate shell
completions.

---

Sorry for the mega-diff. This is mostly mechanically moving stuff around and fitting it in the trait-mold that is similar to `finalfusion-utils`.

title: Set finalfusion to crates.io and bump ndarray dependencies.
body: Mostly renames.

title: Make idx module public.
body: If we want to enable external training implementations this needs to be public. I could've restricted exposure to the trait, but I don't see why the two structs need to be private. #70

title: Remove note about early version, point to quantized embeddings
Extend Metadata with TrainInfo.
body:
Adds TrainInfo holding information about corpus, number of
threads, timestamps and output file.

Adds a section like this to `metadata`:
~~~
[training_info]
corpus = 'tdz-text.conll'
end_datetime = '2019-10-14 12:11:09'
n_threads = 14
output = 'throwaway'
start_datetime = '2019-10-14 12:10:57'
~~~

I'm not too sure about this particular change:

~~~Rust
fn write_model_binary(self, write: &mut W, train_info: TrainInfo) -> Result<(), Error>; 
~~~

This makes assumptions about every model being trained with a `corpus` field, `n_threads` and `output`. We could replace this with `&dyn Serialize`. What do you prefer?

title: Make CountedType constructor pub.
Merge finalfrontier into a single crate
body:
Mostly moving files around. I put most of the `finalfrontier-utils` library stuff into the `io` module. The remainder is now in the `app` module.

We have a lot of crate-level symbols that should probably be removed over time (instead exposing just the submodules).

title: Fix EOS ngrams for NGramVocab.
body: Should fix #72

title: Cap the number of threads at 20 by default
Add version command.
body: Could be nice to set something in CI to fail release-builds to keep the version in sync.

title: Remove dead code an apply tests to live code
body:
The SubwordVocab::subword_indices/indices methods stem from when we
used finalfrontier as a library. However, since that use is gone,
these methods are effectively dead code (we only compute subwords for
known words). This change removes those methods.

The unit tests for these methods were updated to verify the method
that is actually used, SubwordVocab::idx.

---

I noticed this while bug hunting...

title: Support training with explicitly stored ngrams.
body:
Add implementation for SubwordVocab<NGramIndexer> and options for
binaries. finalfusion dependency points to GitHub to access new
features.

title: Generify subword vocab configs.
body:
Factor out some common parameters.

The motivation is that we need some kind of abstraction over the config in the `SubwordVocab`. We could do this through some trait that `Config` types implement, exposing the common parameters or through a struct with a generic field. The trait version looked much hackier, so I went with the generic struct proposed in this PR.

Theoretically we could factor out `discard_threshold` and `min_count` and make a generic `VocabConfig` including one for `SimpleVocab`. I didn't go for this because we'd get pretty deeply nested types with `VocabConfig<SubwordVocabConfig<BucketConfig>>>` and since `SimpleVocab` is a distinct type, we don't need the abstraction either.

title: Update finalfusion dependency and remove subword module.
body:
Replace logic from subword module with implementations from
finalfusion-rust. The updated dependency requires a bump of the
minimal rust version to 1.32.

Part of what I described in #61, I ditched the idea of wrapping full `finalfusion` vocabs because we'd collect indices for every single word in the corpus, even if it is actually OOV.

The subword module & indexer(s) from `finalfusion` still come in handy to implement the `NGramVocab`. Also, if we ever wanted to offer the fastText hashing function, that'd be easily done now.

title: Fix ci and fmt
body: Fixes #64 and addresses the issues that got through CI.

title: Add NGram vocab config.
body:
Add NGram vocab config.

Pretty straight forward, too. This PR introduces a struct holding the hyperparameters for models with explciitly stored ngrams.

Should probably wait for #62 to be merged (or drop the 1st commit if we don't want to restructure)

title: Restructure vocab into module.
body:
Move subword and simple vocabulary implementations to different
files.

Pretty boring stuff but should make working on the vocabs a bit more pleasant.

title: Mark trait objects with dyn
body: Rust 1.37.0 gives warnings for bare trait objects.

title: Lower width of progress bars.
body:
Get width of progress report below 80 columns.

Stops standard-width terminal windows from being spammed.

title: Update finalfusion dependency to 0.7.1 to ensure norms storage
Update dependencies.
body: To avoid accidental, automatic, updates in other PRs.

title: Add support for training without subwords.
body: Once #53 lands, this should be the last required bit to enable training without subwords.

title: Make input vocabulary of depembeds trainer generic.
body: Generifies the input vocabulary of the depembeds trainer. This requires the addition of a lifetime parameter to the TrainIterFrom trait. Else we can't express the required lifetime for the associated `Focus` type since `Box<T>` assumes `T: 'static`.

title: Update license to the Blue Oak Model License 1.0.0
body: Acked by Sebastian Pütz and Nianheng Wu.

title: Change Vocab and Trainers to prepare non-subword training. [Traits, take2]
body:
Yet another approach. This time based on two traits that the index types implement. The main ideas behind this iteration are:
* `SGD` and  `TrainModel` should be agnostic to the index type they receive.
* indexing should be resolved inside `Vocab` and `Trainer`. 
* `SGD` only needs an iterator over the indices, `TrainModel` additionally requires `.len()`. 

The relevant traits are:
* `IndexIterator`, providing `.iter()` over the indices and `.len()`, implemented on references of the index types.
* `WordIdx`, providing `.word_idx()` to get the word idx and `.from_word_idx()` to construct a variant with only a single index.

Integration of the new traits:
* `TrainModel`'s input lookup methods now take `impl IndexIterator` as argument.
*  `TrainIterFrom` has an associated `Focus` type, `update_sentence` places bounds for `&TrainIterFrom::Focus: IndexIterator`
* `NegativeSamplingSGD` now takes `impl IntoIterator<Item=u64>` as argument for inputs.

The indexing types and traits reside in their own `idx` module, since `vocab` started to get quite crowded.

title: Add documentation for the dirgram model
Add directional skipgram into ModelType
Set default values through clap, fix some unsensible defaults
body:
The changed defaults are:

- Context size: 5 -> 10
- Dims: 100 -> 300
- Epochs: 5 -> 15

title: Fix clippy warnings about dangling documentation.

New compiler warnings / clippy warnings about docs not being attached to macros.

The fix is somewhat repetitive but writing another macro to generate the docs seemed unnecessarily complicated.

body:
All the other options use underscores. For regular mincount FREQ is
used.

title: Update the documentation links and README
Fix negative sampling RNGs.
body:
During refactoring, the ZipfRangeGenerator was unintentionally
replaced by an RNG. This commit undoes this change.

Add man page for ff-deps.

This PR is not exactly rocket science, mostly copied from `ff-train.1.md` and changing stuff to make sense for dependency embeddings.

I think that should conclude the dependency-embeddings PRs?

title: Cleanup documentation and style.
body:
Some stylistic/doc stuff I found while skimming through the code I changed. There might be more lurking, but I think there's nothing too obvious left.

Next up is the man page, which is already done. Just didn't want to include it in this PR, too.

title: Add basic AppVeyor config for testing Windows builds
Add projectivization switch.
body:
Adds option to projectivize dependency graphs before training. This is all a bit messier than I hoped. With how the binaries are structured at this point, I couldn't come up with a nice abstraction. For now we could stick with some wrapper struct holding an optional projectivizer: ```Rust struct SentenceIter { inner: Reader, projectivizer: Option

, } ``` and implement `Iterator` for it. There's some ugliness in the `do_work` method because `HeadProjectivizer` doesn't derive `Copy + Clone`.

title: Depembeds bin

Adds the last piece to train dependency embeddings!

sfb833-a3/finalfrontier#55

This is pretty much copy-pasted from the SFB repo. We never merged this on the master branch.

title: Add AppStructs for Depembeds and SkipGram.
body:
Rather light weight changes with lots of lines.

While implementing the `ff-deps` binary I realized I didn't really like the same `AppBuilder` for both training types. I defined `SkipGramApp` and `DepembedsApp` structs that handle all clap-related business and construct all the required configs. The required configs and values can be accessed through getter methods.

Next step after this PR is the actual binary, then clean up (there were some incorrect docs somewhere in the `dep` module)  and we should be ready to release.

title: Travis-CI: Add MUSL target
body: Add MUSL build for Linux x86_64. This produces a static binary that can be deployed on any Linux machine.

title: Automatically build release binaries for tags
body: Perform Linux and macOS 86_64 release builds for git tags and upload them to GitHub releases.

title: Refactor finalfrontier-utils.
body:
I went with a builder struct so we don't have to maintain a lot of duplicated code to add the cmd arguments and construct the config structs. This PR doesn't introduce methods for depembeds, but refactors existing code such that it's really easy to add.

I'm not sure if anyone would use a binary crate's public API, but I think it's worth to mention that the `utils` module is part of the public API. If we don't want to expose these methods, we have to maintain them in all potential binaries.

title: Add Trainer and Config for depembeds.
body:
This commit adds the dep_trainer module and a struct holding
hyperparameters related to dependency embeddings.

title: Fix URLs in README.md.
body: Change links to travis-ci and python module.

title: Migrate to Rust 2018
body:
We were still implicitly on Rust 2015, while at the same time using
post-2018 features. So:

- Switch to Rust 2018
- Also do CI builds on Rust 1.31

The motivation to also test builds against 1.31 is that this is the
first Rust version that supports 2018. Later versions have changes
that are not strictly Rust 2018. I want to stick to 1.31/2018 as the
lowest common denominator for a while, since Linux distributions are
sometimes trailing in Rust versions.

title: Switch rust2vec dependency to finalfusion
Changes to seperate different types of hyperparameters.
body:
This PR looks bigger than it is. Mostly hyperparameters are moved around. Since changes to the config mean changes throughout the entire crate, this commit changes quite a number of files.

To allow more flexibility with different configurations, the `Config` is split up into several specialized structs holding only the hyperparameters relevant to each component.

The `CommonConfig` struct holds those hyperparameters that (at this point?) are shared by all training variants, including e.g. `dims`, `negative_samples` and `loss_type`.
 
Additionally, there are two config structs for vocabularies: `SimpleVocabConfig` and `SubwordVocabConfig`, holding the relevant hyperparameters.

Finally, there is the `SkipgramConfig` which holds settings relevant to skipgram-like training routines, i.e. the `context_window` and `model_type` determining whether vanilla `skipgram` is used or `structgram`.

Since different `Trainer` instantiations can and will have different sets of configurations, changes were necessary to the `WriteModelBinary` impl on `Trainmodel`, too. Instead of converting the `Config` of the `Trainmodel` to a `toml::Value`, `Trainer` now defines a metadata method

```Rust
/// Get this Trainer's hyperparameters as `toml::Value`.
fn to_metadata(&self) -> Result<Value, Error>;
```

leaving it to the `Trainer` implementations to take care of the conversion.

The `SkipgramTrainer`'s takes care of this conversion through an additional struct:

```Rust
#[derive(Clone, Copy, Debug, Serialize)]
struct SkipgramMetadata<V>
where
    V: Serialize,
{
    common_config: CommonConfig,
    #[serde(rename = "model_config")]
    skipgram_config: SkipGramConfig,
    vocab_config: V,
}
```

which is converted to a `toml::Value`.

This framework is compatible with training dependency embeddings without requiring a lot of additional changes. The next steps in my mind are to make the `SkipgramTrainer`'s input vocabulary generic, then adjust `ff-train` accordingly and finally introduce the `DepembedsTrainer` in a third PR. After the `DepembedsTrainer` is there, only minor changes would be left to `ff-train` (or a decision to split things into different crates/binaries).
